item.title: Keystone Correction
item.description: When a projector is placed at an angle to the screen, the projected image becomes distorted into a trapezoid shape instead of a rectangle.

item.title: Lens-shift function
item.description: Lens shift is a mechanical adjustment in a projector that moves the lens inside the projector housing.

item.title: Projector light sources
item.description: Projector light sources fall into two broad families: traditional lamp-based sources and solid-state sources.

item.title: Screaming Architecture
item.description: Screaming Architecture is a concept introduced by renowned software developer and thought leader Robert C. Martin, often referred to as “Uncle Bob”.

item.title: Throw correction
item.description: Throw correction refers to a projector’s ability to adjust the image size and placement relative to the distance between the projector and the screen, without having to physically move the projector.

item.title: Welcome
item.description: The Dinonomicon In a world of scarcity, we treasure tools. In a world of abundance, we treasure taste.
